utterances.speaker: TIMPF

utterances.speaker: EBONI K. WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I'm Eboni K. Williams along with Kat Timpf and Brian Kilmeade. This is "The Fox News Specialists." President Trump's rhetoric over the last 24 hours might be giving some of you a serious case of whiplash. But this afternoon, the president striking unifying tone during a speech to American veterans in Nevada.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: It is time to heal the wounds that divide us and to seek a new unity based on the common values that unite us. We are one people with one home and one great flag. This is the spirit we need to overcome our challenges. To pursue our common destiny, and to achieve a brighter future for our people. We will win. Watch. We will win.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Those remarks today getting some different notes compared to his rally last night in Phoenix where he really attacked the mainstream media.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: The very dishonest media, those people right up there with all the cameras. And I mean truly dishonest people. In the media and the fake media. They make up stories. They have no sources in many cases. They say a source says there is no such thing. But they don't report the facts. These are really, really dishonest people. And they're bad people. And I really think they don't like our country. I really believe that. The only people giving a platform to these hate groups is the media itself and the fake news. The media can attack me, but where I draw the line is when they attack you, which is what they do. When they attack the decency of our supporters.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right, Brian, two very different tones, but also two very different crowds and two very different important moments for the president.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN KILMEADE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I mean, we've three separate styles of speeches in three days in three different audiences. I think it's good he's busy, he's out there. Seventy seven minutes without a script, which it's pretty -- as anyone sitting at this table knows not easy. He will sometimes make four speeches in one day and change all four speeches, not easy. Shows tremendous amount of confidence. But I think that a lot of people, a lot of his critics, instead of looking at that speech, pivoted to he's not mentally well. I waited to see the analysis, see what they liked and didn't like. Instead they pivoted a whole new direction. We think he's not well enough to hold the job. So I'm pretty astounded by that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Deep into that, I know exactly what you're talking about there. Kat, was your take around both of these two kind of different themes but then different audiences?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Right. Again, like I was mentioning yesterday, he tends to go that way when he's at a rally. Brian, it turns out he didn't really take your stand message advice. But I think I know your favorite part and I'm going to read it to you, and Fox & Friends in the morning, it's the best show and it's the absolute most honest show, and it's the show I watch. That was probably.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I did not notice. Do we have a Fox News alert? Can we roll that? But he also loves Sean Hannity.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: He did also say that. But I'm saying this was probably your favorite part of the speech.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right, second favorite.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think you're blushing a little bit, Brian. I like it.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Make up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We'll meet now today's specialist. He's a syndicated radio host, a former aide to Democratic senate minority leader Chuck Schumer, he's a professional improv comic, but he specializes in national politics, Chris Hahn is here. And he's a broadcaster whose career has expanded over 25 years, also an advisor to the vocational educational and training for service members program, and he's a political analyst, but he specializes in being the cofounder of the Tea Party 365 here in New York City, David Webb is here. So let's kick things off. Almost on cue, the mainstream media went into just full string pandemonium following President Trump's Phoenix rally.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: What a dramatic shift from the somber commander-in- chief the night before. Remember, he called on the whole country to come together in unity, but last night he was angry. He was raw. He was divisive. He was deceptive.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Abandoning his carefully scripted remarks from a day earlier, Mr. Trump was unrestrained, lashing out in a tirade that started with the call for unity. The president again defending his highly criticized response to the clashes in Charlottesville.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It was deeply disturbing and offensive the way he spoke of the media. But what Donald Trump speech is not deeply disturbing and offensive?

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: He's unhinged. It's embarrassing, and I don't mean for us the media because he went after us, but for the country.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK, Chris. So is this the media taking the bait from President Trump do you think? Because, I mean, as Kat points out accurately, he's talking to his base, right, in this type of rally space. So we can expect that type of tone, that type of texture, that type of energy from the president, so is this a bit of an overreaction from the media?

utterances.speaker: CHRIS HAHN, SYNDICATED RADIO HOST
utterances.utterance: You know, I think the media always overreact to just about everything. I know I do sometimes when I'm on the radio because.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Because of him though, right?

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, look, he is different than anything we've ever seen, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: And this is not necessarily a good kind of different. The country is right now hurting over what happened in Charlottesville. And going to Arizona where there could have been a riot. If it wasn't 106 degrees in Arizona, yesterday, God knows what could've happened there, right? So we have a president going out there and feeding red meat to his base, which, you know, if it was six weeks before an election, perfectly appropriate. He just got elected. He's only been in office for seven months. The nation is in a crisis. He needs to be bringing people together and not fostering divisions which is what he was doing last night.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think I saw a chuckle, David Webb. Your take on it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID WEBB, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Well, first of all, I was on Fox & Friends this morning with Brian Kilmeade. So there we go.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: That's right. You know, Barack Obama never went on the campaign trail. All presidents gone to campaign trail and fire up their base. Let's look at their speeches. The media is going to paint him as angry and divisive. Eugene Robinson, Don Lemon, they're never going to paint an accurate picture. In that clip we've played your people say, well, the night before, the tone on the new southeast strategy, different than the campaign. They're stating the obvious, but take it to the extreme. And the fact is when you look at what he said today, when you look at what he said in phoenix, when he talked the American legion, when he talked to the veterans. Veterans that are suffering in Louisiana where there are long wait lines. Other V.A. issues. In Washington, D.C., our nation's capital, we have a V.A. director.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: All presidents do fire up there base, but not all of them called George Stephanopoulos a tiny little man.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: So there is a difference.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: . acknowledge there's a difference, you may like that?

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: No, I didn't say there wasn't a difference. But here's my point, you don't have a politican which is what we had in the White House before, and that's what I call them. They come out with a politics speech, they make it sound as if it's true.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Dave, I love you. David Webb. I want to make this very clear before I do this, right. I love you before I shoot you down here. The president lies even when he quotes himself. Last night he yada-yada over what the biggest controversy was over his speeches. And I say yada-yada.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Which one?

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Because he made me miss Seinfeld because he went late last night. Usually I like him because he used to keep it short.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: I know and I've seen everyone 25 times. But he yada-yada over the both side, over there's some bind people marching with the white supremacists over his.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Actually, Chris, and here is what I will suggest to you and everyone out there. I'll email it to you. I'll actually email you a transcript of what he said when it came to Charlottesville, and you can choose intellectual honesty or you can choose intellectual dishonesty about his words. You can debate the terms he used, but you cannot debate the full context of his speech. By the way, you sit here and you say very comfortably, and you have for years. We've known each other for too long. The president lies. Barack Obama lied. The other presidents have lied. Politicians lied to us every day. Chuck Schumer, who you used to work for, lied continuously. So what are we going to take away from this? I want the actions and policy. And if we can't focus on that, the problem is.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Was he comprehensive when he was quoting himself last night? Was he comprehensive?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: He left off the part where he said both sides.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: If I can insert one thing into this, so George Stephanopoulos, for the most part, used to be on a call in a weekly basis with the previous administration when Rahm Emanuel was there. He was doing a new show and he had this insight to administration who's clearly rooting for it. So other politicians for the most part would say, I'm going to sit down with Stephanopoulos, I wonder how I should handle this. You know what Trump says? George, you know, you worked with Bill Clinton. I know exactly where you stand. Hey, you're a little guy. Marco Rubio, you're a little guy. Rand Paul he pulled on the stage.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: He's a blue-collar guy talking to the American people.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: He almost does it in a way to label his.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: But he's the president now.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: The criticism that I hear all the time is that the media won't let President Trump talk about his agenda or his policies, which to an extent, a lot of the media isn't fair. However, how does he help himself when he uses his time to say, you know, he begins a speech with this movement was built on love, then halfway through he's talking about George Stephanopoulos.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying in terms of how does this help him get his message out?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Great question, here's the answer. It's about getting the base, which I think the president is very comfortable with, Kat. I think that a lot of people think that at some point he's going to try to grow the base. No, he's not going to grow the base. They got him in the White House. I think he's content with that base. And so that's how it helped him. He sees the narrative -- I'm going to flip Kat's question though on her. And you don't have to be the only one to answer it. It's open to the table. How does the media though, do themselves a favor by constantly I'm going to call it taking the bait. What if they took the approach to listen to the expected tone and the red meat, I agree, that President Trump gave his base in Phoenix, and then said, well, that's about what we can expect from the president and then pivots.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I think they're having fun.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Well, no, here's my point with this. This is what the Democrats are looking at. The Russia, they haven't delivered a thing in ten months. They haven't delivered evidence or an indictment. So right now they need to pivot. So now they need to paint the president as unfit for office. They tried this about six weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Winter is coming.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But Chris, I further define it.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I remember now where this Stephanopoulos thing came from. He gets an interview with Nikki Haley at which time they want to talk about the war in Afghanistan, a serious subject and a serious policy. Something that has pluses and minuses from the best -- worst military mind. He gets one question about that and then tries to get him as to Matt Lauer. Seven different ways on Charlottesville the week before. It looked like an agenda to make the president look bad because they weren't happy, but the speech came off OK. So instead of this president backing up and writing a memoir, he responds the next day in front of 15,000 people.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: That's what people.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: The country wants to talk about Charlottesville. It's not just the media. I mean, if you go on social media, everybody is still talking about Charlottesville and what the president did about it. What he said about both sides. He has not come clean fully on it. He should apologize to the American people is what he should do.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Apologize for what, Chris?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: He wasn't responsible for the wreckage in Charlottesville.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's not responsible for what occurred in Charlottesville, whatsoever, but he is accountable for his response.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . to Charlottesville. And I think that's what a lot.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Most of the majority of Americans were not satisfied with it.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: The majority of the country is not going as manic on Charlottesville as the media would like to portray.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But David, you host a radio show. You host a radio show. I host a radio show. Well, let me tell you what my listeners are talking about, David. They are concerned with how they're going to eat, how their kids to get to school, and they're concerned that the racial tensions in this moment in the country, as they have been escalating pre-Donald Trump going to the White House, but they feel like they're reaching a fever pitch, and they are concern about that.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Where did that begin, 2014, Ferguson.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, it even came before that.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: No, where did the fever pitch begin? I was in Ferguson for two weeks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We should talk about how it began. But in this moment, David, we have to address where we are.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Stop me if I'm wrong. You know the number one thing in this is the statues. I cannot -- every other call is about these statues. We're taking our last look at Christopher Columbus. If we don't start soon, I'm telling you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I hate the conflation of the statue argument, not that you're making it, I think people.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: We're not conflating it. The mayor of New York is talking about it. The city council.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: And by the way, are we going to change the name of Columbia University or are we going to change the name of Washington, D.C., district of Columbia?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I would love for the people of this country to decide those issues, David, for themselves.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We still have enough to talk about here at The Specialist today. Before we go, a quick programming note, you'll love this, Brian, be sure to watch Brian tomorrow on that great program, Fox & Friends. They've got an exclusive interview with Arizona senator Jeff Flake. It should be very interesting to say the least. But up next, President Trump threatens a government shutdown over the border wall. Could the lights soon be going out in D.C.? Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Well, it would not be a proper Trump rally without talk of a border wall. Last night in Phoenix, the president added another twist to his long standing pledge.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Build that wall. Now the obstructionist Democrats would like us not to do it, but believe me, we have to close down our government. We're building that wall. Let me be very clear to Democrats in congress who oppose a border wall and stand in the way of border security, you are putting all of America's safety at risk.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, House Speaker Paul Ryan responded to that threat of a shutdown over the border wall this afternoon.

utterances.speaker: REP. PAUL RYAN, R-WIS., HOUSE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: I don't think a government shutdown is necessary, and I don't think most people want to see a government shutdown, ourselves included. And congress in the house has already done its work on this issue.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: They did. They put aside $1.6 billion. They threw it into a spending bill. They gave it to the senate where we'll have an ugly debt. And the senate needs 60 votes to pass it. And yet, I believe that the Democrats would understand that in the most part they need the barrier built up, fencing a wall at some places, but they won't do it because it would be the ultimate victory for the president who they are enjoying not giving legislative victory to.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I see it in a different way which is that I agree, there've been Democrats who've gone on record via vote and otherwise to talk about some need for fencing and other parts of shoring up the border, right?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Including Hillary Clinton.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Including Hillary Clinton. So what if the president -- I don't know, tried to beat them at their own game? If the game is totally obstruction. Let's take your premise here. And say, you know what, let's come to the table with a comprehensive plan with the goal stated purpose of shoring up the border in a variety of ways and call their bluff. What about that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: With all about the border, you're saying?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Because you can't do comprehensive.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, all about the border.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: All about the border.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Well, David, I mean, this is the kind of thing that President Trump says during his rallies, and people are going to get all fired up. Love the wall. Yeah, we'll shove it up. Does he really mean it?

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Whether he means it or not, you can go back to 2006 when the appropriations -- where, actually, done the investigation was done and it was written, given to congress. So there're already existing structures to be used within the appropriations process. And if they go back to regular order, they could actually do this in this budget. So everyone talks about the speech. I'm talking about what already exists in law and in appropriations. And they're actually progressing on this. The bad news for the obstructionist is there are a variety of methods that have been brought to the table, they're being reviewed. The White House has already made decisions not letting the EPA get in the way in certain cases where they're going to find a way to block it, that deep state embed of bureaucrats. So I've got bad news.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: The first rule about winning a government shutdown fight is stop threatening that you're going to shut down the government as the president did last night. Second, we're not going to back to regular order. It's not going to be about the border wall that shutdown. There is going to be a debt ceiling vote in three weeks that's going to fail not because of Democrats but because of your pals in the tea party or whenever they're calling themselves now.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: You can try the tone, it doesn't work with me. I've been on this game longer than you. So here's how it actually works.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: You say you're older than me?

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: I don't care and neither do most of the American people if there is a shutdown because it's just like the senate vacation.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: They will when they don't get their social security checks.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: That, by the way, doesn't get interrupted. So essential services and those things go forward. It's the typical shutdown is 12 to 17 percent of government may be affected for a low then payback. The American people get the message. So it's great to sit up here and use the tones and try to get across, but the fact is most people are saying get something done. The American people elected Trump, independent.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: The American people are knocking leadership out of the White House. He did not lead on health care. He will not lead on a border wall. He will not lead on a budget. He will not lead.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Chris, would you say it's leading to say, listen, I want this wall and if not, I'll shutdown the government.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: You don't like the leader, but he is taking the lead there. Paul Ryan says, well, I don't want that. That's fine. You don't need three people saying the same thing.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: I think that the senate majority leader would disagree with his tactics. And he needs the senate majority leader more than the senate majority leader needs him.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: He's not -- the senate majority leader is not doing a great job of being a senate majority leader.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Mitch McConnell is probably had his last straw with the president when he endorsed Flake's opponent.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: He didn't formally endorsed Flake's opponent. He pointed out.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Yeah, kind of did. If I was her, I would take it as an endorsement. In fact, I've seen her all over TV saying, I'm so happy the president endorsed me.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: By the way, Mitch McConnell, 18 percent approval in his state. President Trump, 60. I think in Kentucky.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Mitch McConnell is not up in 2020.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Here is something exceptional. When the president said shutdown, the market dropped 66 points. So they do not want to see a government shutdown. They didn't like that move.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: But what's the long-term effect of a government shutdown? Very nothing.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: We've got to go to the next block. We've got to go. We've got to go to the next block. Up next, why is the founder of the firm behind the Trump dossier refusing to identify clients in the senate judiciary committee? And later, ESPN brings political correctness to really an all- time low, pulling a broadcaster just for having the name Robert Lee. How mean. Don't go away.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: All right. The founder of Fusion GPS, the opposition research firm behind the notorious Trump dossier getting grilled on Capitol Hill behind closed doors. It was Glenn Simpson squaring off with the senate judiciary committee's staffers or investigators, and they say it's a ten hour closed-door session that happened yesterday. Now, one of the lingering questions, of course, is who funded this salacious Trump dossier since his lawyer said Simpson answered a lot of questions but he would not give up any client names. So will investigators be able to get to the answers? And if he will not give up the names will he ever get those answers? David, how significant. We have not heard any leaks, really substantive leaks, come out of this meeting. We do know we're not going to hear about the clients yet.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: We're not going to hear about them yet, but let's see where this goes with the Mueller investigation and the dossier. Glenn Simpson was brought it. He spent ten hours there. He also brought up something else interesting, and this has been leaked out of Washington. Was it a big Republican donor who paid for the dossier? I would suggest people read what Chuck Ross has been doing on the story. He's carried it in the Daily Collar. And right now there's going to be more coming out. Ten hours is a lot to cover. Ten hours, Democrats and Republicans were present. And those clients, well, if they subpoena and start bringing this into part of the prosecution. And Eboni, you're the attorney, then those clients do have to be revealed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was going to say, yes. He, obviously, necessarily won't have to, but subpoena power is strong, Brian and David. And certainly, that can compel up to the penalty of contempt, and certainly no one is going, I think, risk that. So at some point, those names very well will come out.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: And he wants the transcripts released. He basically made a statement yesterday, saying, senate committee has my testimony. They have the right to release that transcript. He would like to see it released. I think a lot of people would like to read it. I know I like to read it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I would assume though that a subpoena would be what it would take. Of course, they're not going to release those names. No one is going to use this service. It's like number one snitching in your business.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Right. But it's not lawyer-client privilege and that's what we have to realize here. This is not privilege information. TIMPF: Of course it's not. I'm just saying in terms of their own business.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Don't want to make it even worse.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Let's say you're a Republican operatives, and you're an opponent of Donald Trump, and you -- I don't know -- lose. So you have this opposition research.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: It's gold.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: And there's only one person that wants it. Hillary Clinton.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Price tag. Yes, and price tag.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Did she get it? Did she get it?

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Ii don't think so.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Did she use it?

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: What happened to it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If she used it, she didn't do a very good job.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Doesn't seem like she used it, to me.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: The most intriguing thing to come out of this, and the guy that I want to hear from is Christopher Steele. He's the one who actually, evidently had some respect for the MI-5, went into Russia, evidently had some contacts. Other people have poked some holes.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: I don't think you'd be his favorite broadcaster if you had Christopher Steele on the couch with you.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right. I'm just -- to have Christopher Steele tell us what he found out, how he put it together, and what's behind it.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Here's what I'd pay close attention to, an ongoing case in the United Kingdom related to this company, to Fusion GPS. What happens, what comes out in the U.K., started about five weeks ago, may well give us an indication -- and it does -- of what's going to come out in the United States.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: I hope Christopher Steele testifies. I can't wait. It's going to be -- it's going to be the most fantastic -- It's going to be better than the "Game of Thrones" finale next weekend. That's all I've got to say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'd like to...

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: OK, that's going a bit far.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'd like to take it around the table. And that is, how does everybody feel around closed-door versus open-door testimony? Because we've seen both a lot recently. You could say for a while now in Washington. Which do you prefer? Closed-door or -- I would say you get more from closed-door. But...

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: The advantage to closed-door is the queen for a day principal that you know exists in law. You come in, you're queen for a day. You get a chance to talk. You get a chance without an indictment. Then they make decisions where to go forward, based on what you've given. I like that. But I do want the open testimony on the record after a while. That's what our elected representatives are supposed to do.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I think Donald Trump -- I'm sorry, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I agree. I mean, closed-door, you can -- I was going to say, you can get more. But open, I get more.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Right. Right.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: And I get to be able to watch it and know what's going on; and I really, really always like that. I prefer that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: You know what I find fascinating? I'm a closed-door-open-door person. I'll go both ways. But I will say this. Don Trump Jr. is now trying to get behind closed doors, I understand, to do that. What I find fascinating is every time there's an interesting Republican, somebody that could help the Republican, nothing leaks.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: And every time there's a Democrat -- and they're in the minority -- every time there's a Democrat that goes behind closed doors, you might as well put it on a horn.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Look, I am all for open-door, but if there's something that's of national security interests, you know, you've got to have it behind closed doors. So if you're doing a behind closed doors thing, and they're giving you stuff that is not classified, that should be released to the public, period.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: But also consider...

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: There should be a waiting period, but it should be released to the public. The public has a right to know. We live in a republic, not in, you know, some closed-door society.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: But let's do consider there's an ongoing investigation. So you may not want to compromise anything that the special counsel or the Senate committees are doing.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Where's the special counsel on this? They should get the first shot at everybody.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Oh, he's working.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: The other two -- the other two investigations should take a second...

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: He's busy. He's busy.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Why does he get -- why doesn't Mueller get Glenn Simpson.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think everybody's first round should be closed-door and then, if it's not a security risk, then we do open.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Then the Democrats will leak it anyway.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Just not at 5 p.m., because we don't want it infringing on your hour. OK?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: We've got to close the door, make sure you're done by five. Meanwhile, coming up straight ahead, when we return, the most boneheaded PC move of all time done by ESPN. Inexplicable decision to remove one of its broadcasters to Youngstown, Ohio, because his name is Robert Lee, and he's Asian.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Welcome back to "The Fox News Specialists." Our specialists today are Chris Hahn and David Webb. Let's continue the conversation. What do these two guys have in common? I don't know. I don't really know either of them that well, but they do share a first and last name. The guy on your left is ESPN broadcaster Robert Lee. The guy on your right, Confederate General Robert E. Lee. Just the mere coincidence of their names so offended the delicate sensibilities of ESPN that it pulled Robert Lee, the broadcaster, from covering an upcoming University of Virginia football game in Charlottesville. Because of course, the mere sound of "Robert Lee" during a discussion about UVA's field goal kicker may trigger a flood of emotions about the Civil War's Confederate statues. Thus, ESPN has at last secured the championship trophy for worldwide leader in PC stupidity.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'd like to take this moment, in all seriousness, and say that this is complete validation of my insistence of using a middle initial. See how important it is? Eboni K. Williams has saved me. So I really want to take a moment to encourage everybody to use that middle initial.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Unless, of course, it's...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It isn't me. I know. It might be. It might be.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Can I -- can I just say...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The odds are one to 26 that I'm OK.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Can I take this moment to congratulate Robert Lee's publicist, who came up with this idea?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I was going to say, he's famous.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: He's going to be -- he is going to be the most famous sportscaster. It's going to be Joe Buck, Robert Lee. He's going to be doing the Super Bowl by the end of the year. OK? We never heard about him until today. Now everybody's talking about him.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Right. The claim was, ESPN said it was a mutual thing, because they thought, you know, there might be some meme if Robert Lee...

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: There might be some memes. Oh, the memes! Oh, you know, memes. Come on.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Robert -- OK, first of all, we haven't heard from him yet on this. This is a guy who worked hard to become a broadcaster, was promoted. This first game, by the way, a very -- one of those football games, UVA against William and Mary. This is a big game. But here's the real idiocy...

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: ... versus PC. So Robert Lee, because of his name, is not allowed to be the broadcaster. So ESPN has a problem with an Asian-American broadcaster.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Dave...

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Then you've got the -- the further idiocy of the Columbus statues that I mentioned earlier. They're now going...

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Dave, Robert Lee did this himself. This is Robert Lee doing this. His publicist did this.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: No, ESPN made the decision.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: No way.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Well, let me finish anyway, Chris.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Now we have further idiocy in California in USC, because their mascot, a white horse that gallops across the field with the trojan and the raised sword, is named Traveler with one "L," and General Robert E. Lee's horse was named Traveller with two "L's." So now they're calling for the mascot to be renamed. I'm telling you, the liberal stupidity and the PC has become idiocy.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: And Brian, this is my problem. It's because it's gone beyond just, OK, we'll stop doing anything if some person gets offended. Used to be bad enough, one person get offended. Now people are preemptively living their lives with every move. Someone on the Internet might be offended by this. Someone might blog. Someone might go after me. And they're kind of restraining the way that they would normally live.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: How about this, Kat? People 19, 20 and 21 years old, the University of North Carolina at Duke, are now going to spend their first week of school, instead of finding their books and building lofts in their dorm, they are going to be protesting the existence of Confederate statues, including Robert E. Lee.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: They should.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's actually not new.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: They should.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Actually, Brian, I went to -- as you know, proud Tarheel. You know, many of us have been protesting Silent Sam and some of those statues for -- I mean, I came out of school 15 years ago. So that's actually not new.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I would say this, but I'd like to add this. If I was -- if I was insulted by Silent Sam or some -- Fighting Irish of Notre Dame...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We were talking about it.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: ... I would say, "Listen, I'm going to be insulted by that." I'd choose another school. Silent Sam is part of the...

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Robert E. Lee...

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: ... of that school. Don't go to the school with Confederate generals.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: ... committed treason.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Stop, stop. I assure you, I did not go to UNC, Chapel Hill because of Silent Sam. That is not true. That is not true.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Guys....

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So I just want to make that very clear. That's what you just said, right?

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Take them down.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But if a school presents their program to me, and they say, "This is what my campus looks like. This is what I have in my school. This is what I offer," I'll make that -- if they accept me, I'll take that school if I want. I wouldn't go to that school and then try to change it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me tell you what I did. They not only accepted me; they gave me a full academic merit scholarship. And what I did, what prepared me to sit at this table with you fine people today, is we had dialogue. We had exchanges. And it was amazing, because it gave me the training wheels to be able to have intellectual discourse with people that sometimes you agree with and sometimes you don't. It's amazing.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: But what you don't have right now...

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: There you go. Better said than I was.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: ... this debate, if you want to go and start this process of who gets to decide. I brought this up a week ago on the show. Who gets to decide what statues to remove? Then get rid of Arlington, Virginia, get rid of all these names. Go to colleges. There are so many names tied to the Confederacy. Stonewall Jackson out in Brooklyn, because they were on the base. You've got Hamilton. You know, you've got all these...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm not suggesting all. I'm not suggesting all.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Now we can't go to the Roman Colosseum, because it was built by slave labor. Can't go to the Egyptian pyramid.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Well, look, Mohammed had slaves.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Admiral Nelson, there's a huge statue.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Here in America, we should not be celebrating people who committed treason on this country and led to the deaths of 600,000 of our countrymen.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: But Chris -- Chris...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: At least we should debate it. At least we should debate it.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: They need not to have statues, right?

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: First of all...

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: There's no statues to losers. There's no Bill Buckner statue in Boston. Why are there statues to the losers who fought -- it's embarrassing.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: He was a great player. He was an excellent player.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: But there's no statue to him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Too many Daves (ph) on this show. Now you know you stepped on toes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: ... defensive replacement.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: You know what? There's a really serious point that needs to be made here, and Chris, it might sound funny...

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: ... but let's have a moment when we actually have an intellectually honest and serious moment about this issue.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think we just had one, by the way.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: But let's go a little bit further with this. Not only who gets to decide when, but there's something important about history and the history of the world. You mentioned the Romans. You go back to the fact that Romans had slaves; Egyptians had slaves. Mohammed had slaves. Slavery has been going on for the last 150 years, still goes on somewhere in the world. History is not written in moments. It's written in the evolution of societies.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: We are not static. Therefore, as a society, we have evolved. By erasing the history, you erase the lessons learned. Or you remove them from public view.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: No. Taking down the statues of racists.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I say, I'm not in favor of the removal of all these statutes whatsoever. I'm in favor of the discussion.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: The problem is we're not having the discussion, to Kat's point about preemptive thinking. Oh, come on. Traveler at USC?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm not talking about that.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: I know...

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: I think it was Will Rogers' horse. OK? Let's go with that.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Well, there's no word on whether or not anyone is protesting outside of the home of Robert Lee's parents for giving him that name. Coming up, excerpts from Hillary Clinton's upcoming book get released, and they're chock full of low blows to President Trump. Don't go away.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Shocker.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes. Very shocking news.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Excerpts from Hillary Clinton's memoir, "What Happened?," getting leaked to the media today that include audio clips from Hillary actually reading from the book. She takes some very personal shots at President Trump over her experience during the debates.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, D-FORMER PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
utterances.utterance: It was incredibly uncomfortable. He was literally breathing down my neck. My skin crawled. It was one of those moments where you wish you could hit pause and ask everyone watching, "Well, what would you do? Do you stay calm, keep smiling, carry on as if he weren't repeatedly invading your space? Or do you turn, look him in the eye and say loudly and clearly, 'Back up, you creep'?"

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK, strong words from Mrs. Clinton. David, your response?

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: I would have bought her a piece of chalk so she could have a safe space. You got on the main stage. You wanted to be crowned queen of the Democrat Party. Your party put the tip -- their finger on the scale, the party leadership, against your opponent, Bernie Sanders. And now she needs a new narrator. Look, Hillary Clinton is writing a second book that will basically not be bought by any but her base. She's rewriting her story to tell her side of the story. Some will buy it; some will not. But in large part, I think it's time for the Clintons and the Clintons to leave the stage and take the '90s with them.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Well, first David...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: It's the Democratic Party. Your war on grammar always gets me. OK? I don't understand it. So look...

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Actually, it's legally called the Democratic Party.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: It's the Democratic Party. I've been there, OK?

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: It's the Democrat Party.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: It is -- it is unreal to me that people would be offended by her book. Yes, he did look like he was stalking her. Everybody talked about it. I talked about it. You talked about it. But that said, I agree with you on one thing. It is time for the Democratic Party to move on from the Clintons.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: And it is time -- happy that this book is coming out now and not during the 2018 election or the 2020 election. Because it can't be about them anymore. It's time for us to move on to new leadership. People like Cheryl Samburg or John Hickenloop or people like that who might lead the Democratic Party in the next...

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: I didn't know you were an adjective, but it's nice to know.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I would say this. I'm pretty amazed that we're still interested in this. I thought "Shattered" told the story.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It was supposed to be an homage to the run of the first woman to become president. But she still doesn't even sound natural on her own audiobook.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: I know. She needs...

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I got a little sleepy.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: She was a bad narrator. She would have been a great president. But it's time to move on.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: What I don't understand is she's still doing the same thing where she thinks everyone wants to hear so much about why other people -- he was mean to me; he was mean to me. You really can't run a campaign or live your life like that. You can't.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Somebody did ask her to write a book and pay her a lot of money to do it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: A kid running for student council wouldn't run a campaign like that, because other kids would make fun of them and throw pencils at them.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: What's she going to do? Someone paid her to write a book.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: What's the return on investment on the millions they gave her?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Remember Al Gore? Remember walking by George Bush? He was talking, he goes, "Hi." That's what he does. That's part of the intimidation. How much do you want to be president?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I would say this. There's another book that comes out the same day as Mrs. Clinton's. And in it, there's an interview with Frank Luntz, a colleague and friend of many of ours. And I thought Frank gave really candid advice, which is you know, he can approach it like you're saying, Brian, you know, kind of the intimidation, which I think is, by the way, fair game.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Political intimidation is part of the game.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's a fair thing, absolutely. Or -- Barack Obama struggled with it. You know, he didn't know where the line was either. You know, are you being too mean, are you not being nice? We talked about that infamous line of when, I think Barack Obama thought he was being funny when he said, "You know, you're nice enough." And many people felt that that was inappropriate.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Or when Bill Clinton said he would have been bringing us coffee.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: New Hampshire. Yes. So we talked a lot about that. Because I think it's difficult to gauge what's appropriate, what's too much, what's crowding and what's really fair game. And you're just stepping into the arena as an equal, politically and otherwise.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: By the way, there is not...

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: If you want to keep an eye on a woman, Governor Haley. That -- look for her to emerge. You have to...

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: I agree. I think that she is probably the rising star in the Republican Party.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A hundred percent.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: She's probably going to rise in this administration. I wouldn't be surprised if she's on the ticket in 2020. I know a lot of people don't like to hear that, but I think that she -- I think that she is a rising star. I think she's done well for herself in this administration, in the administration has been very hard for people to do well from the South, she shines.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: She does very well.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Considering she supported Marco Rubio. She was pushing Marco Rubio. Now she's a...

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Not only that. She did hit Trump quite a bit. A lot.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: He gets over that.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: Amazingly he still hired her amongst all these other women that are in the administration. Funny how that works. Politics, to Eboni's point, is a full-contact sport. utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: By the way, there's no way they'll ever have Donald Trump without Mike Pence. They're inseparable, get along.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: It was a great decision to team the two up. It really brought the wing together.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Don't be so sure about that. Don't be so sure about that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: You have an in source?

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: I think -- I think that there's always -- you know, this president doesn't like people who get ahead of him. Right? Look what happened to Steve Bannon. And at times, there've been a lot of people on the right saying, "We would really like to have that Mike Pence."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This feels very "House of Cards" to me.

utterances.speaker: WEBB
utterances.utterance: It feels like Chris projected.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: I feel that guy is -- the president doesn't have to ask anybody who's going to be his vice president.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: If there's anyone trustworthy in the administration, it's Mike Pence.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We've got to now say goodbye to our specialists.

utterances.speaker: HAHN
utterances.utterance: Get ready, baby.

utterances.utterance: OK. David Webb and Chris Hahn, thank you both so much for joining us. But up next, "Wait, What?" Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Now, it's time for our last segment of the day, unless Bret Baier overslept. We'll have to go a little longer. It's time for...

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: "Wait, What?"

utterances.utterance: Yes, and I'm going to start. Here's the way, Eboni and Kat, we could find out if Donald Trump gets a 53rd senator in the Senate. It turns out Bob Menendez is under indictment. If something happens and Menendez is forced out, the Democrat from New Jersey, guess who gets to appoint the next senator? A Republican governor named Chris Christie

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Chris Christie.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: And that's how No. 53 could come in for No. 45.

utterances.utterance: "House of Cards," baby. I love it. All right, mine up. OK, so we've got these lovely devices, all three of us with our phones on set all day. utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I love this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So you would opt into the 20 percent discount?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I would do that. I'd put it towards the tip for the waiter or waitress.

utterances.utterance: Would you opt into it, Kat?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Would you need to text?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Basket of phones? Wouldn't germs spread that way?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's really the most important point.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I'm always thinking about germs spreading.

utterances.utterance: Finally.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF

utterances.utterance: She is lucky. She is a star.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: She cry, cry, cries in her lonely heart.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Not toxic. Not toxic.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Sorry, Andrew Jackson. You're out of luck. What exactly have you accomplished? Britney Spears. Oops, she did it again.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's the best one. Good job.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.
